name: Idli
history: Idli is a traditional South Indian dish believed to have originated in present-day Karnataka. It has been a staple breakfast item in South Indian households for centuries.
description: Idli is a soft and fluffy steamed cake made from a fermented batter of rice and black lentils. It is known for its light texture and mild flavor, typically served with chutney and sambar.

equipment.name: idli steamer or idli cooker
equipment.description: Specialized equipment used to steam idlis.

equipment.name: blender or grinder
equipment.description: Used for grinding the rice and lentils into a fine batter.

equipment.name: mixing bowl
equipment.description: A bowl used for fermenting the batter.

instructions.title: Soak and Grind
instructions.description: Soak the rice, urad dal, and fenugreek seeds in water for 6-8 hours. Drain and grind them to a smooth batter, adding water as needed.

instructions.title: Ferment the Batter
instructions.description: Transfer the batter to a large bowl. Add salt and allow it to ferment in a warm place for 8-12 hours, until it doubles in size.

instructions.title: Steam the Idlis
instructions.description: Grease the idli molds and pour the batter into each mold. Steam in an idli steamer or cooker for 10-15 minutes, or until the idlis are cooked and fluffy.

instructions.title: Serve
instructions.description: Remove the idlis from the molds and serve hot with chutney and sambar.

tips: The consistency of the batter is key; it should be neither too thick nor too runny.
Ensure the steamer or cooker is well heated before placing the idli molds for steaming.
variations: Rava Idli: Made with semolina instead of rice and urad dal, without the need for fermentation.
Masala Idli: Add finely chopped vegetables and spices to the batter before steaming.

storage.shelfLife: Idli batter can be stored in the refrigerator for up to 2 days.
storage.instructions: Store the batter in an airtight container. Steamed idlis can also be refrigerated.

reheatingInstructions: Reheat steamed idlis in a microwave or steamer until warm.
presentationTips: Serve idlis on a banana leaf for a traditional presentation.
